msClasses package¶

Submodules¶

msClasses.Gaussian module¶

Class for fitting and plotting 3 parameter Gaussian distributions.

class msClasses.Gaussian.Gaussian[source]¶
calculateAmplitude(xval)[source]¶

Return Gaussian... think this is an unfinished function

estimateParameters(xvals, yvals, setValues=True)[source]¶
Estimate values for the 3 parameter Gaussian
The estimation is crude and is usually used to determine initial values for

optimise parameters, which is much more robust. | If setValues is True, use the estimated parameters as the values for self.amplitude, self.centre and self.fwhm. | Otherwise values are returned as a list [amplitude,centre,fwhm]

getData(xvals)[source]¶
Generates the associated Gaussian y values for the supplied xvals (which should be a numpy array or scalar).
self.amplitude, self.centre and self.fwhm should already have been set
optimiseParameters(xvals, yvals, setValues=1)[source]¶
Use non linear least squares to fit the parameters of the

Gaussian. | setValues means the optimised parameters are set to this object, else the parameters are returned as a dictionary.

plot(xvals, ax, **kwargs)[source]¶
Plot the Gaussian using the objects Gaussian parameters
All matplotlib.pyplot.plot() arguments are allowed in **kwargs.
setParameters(amplitude, centre, fwhm)[source]¶

Set the values for a three parameter Gaussian

msClasses.MassSpectrum module¶

Class for deconvoluting and plotting native mass spectra.

class msClasses.MassSpectrum.MassSpectrum[source]¶

Bases: msClasses.TwoDdata.TwoDdata

Class for storing and deconvoluting mass spectra

Inherits from TwoDdata: def __init__(self) def readFile(self,filename,x_range=0,grain=1) def normalisationBpi(self) def normalisationArea(self) def setNormalisationType(self,type) def smoothingSG(self,window_len=3,smoothes=2,poly_order=1) def _normalisePreset(self) def restoreRawYvals(self) def getAxesWithoutNans(self) def calculateWeightedMeanStandardDeviation(self) def calculateAreaUnderCurve(self) def _calculateGradient(self) def findPeaks(self,limit=0) def addPeak(self,mz) def plot(self,ax,**kwargs) def plotgPeaks(self,ax,labels=0,**kwargs)

addSpecies(speciesObj, allowReplace=False)[source]¶

Add a Species() object to the MassSpectrum.species dictionary. This allows it to be used in the fitting procedure. allowReplace means adding a second species with the same name to overwrite existing items in the dictionary.

errorCalculations(xvals)[source]¶

Calculates and prints to console error statistics for comparing the simulated spectrum to the original data. + average error per data point + average error per m/z unit + RMSD (root mean square deviation)

forLeastSquaresOptimisation(p0, xvals, zs, oneFwhm)[source]¶

Creates the simulated mass spectrum for MassSpectrum.leastSquaresOptimisation(). p0 - parameters to be used in simulation zs - charges to be simulated oneFwhm - if True use same FWHM for each species.

getPeakWidthLimits(name, charge, leftMultiplier=1, rightMultiplier=1)[source]¶

Calculate the lower and upper m/z limits for a particular peak in relation to the multiplier values. (only use after calculating the mass spectrum fit).

Parameters:
  • name – Species name
  • charge – Charge to display
  • leftMultiplier – Value to multiply the peak fwhm below the mean
  • rightMultiplier – Value to multiply the peak fwhm above the mean
Returns:

m/z limits when using multiplier as [lowerLimit,upperLimit]
getgPeaksFromIds(ids)[source]¶

Generates a new gPeaks dictionary containing only the gPeaks with the supplied ids. gPeak format is gPeak[id] = [mz,intensity]

leastSquaresOptimisation(speciesNames, oneFwhm=False)[source]¶

Deconvolute mass spectrum using non linear least squares. Setting oneFwhm to true results in the same value for peak full width half height being used for all species.

plotAllComponents(ax, xvals, yvals, liftPercentage=10, speciesNames=0, colourList=0, traceLabels='mass', labelSize='small', **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot mass spectrum, each of the deconvoluted elements and the simulated spectrum traceLabels can be ‘mass’ or ‘name’, with name the Species name is printed on the right tail of the trace. Species names allow you to change the order of the list All matplotlib.pyplot.plot() arguments are allowed in **kwargs.

plotPeakWidthLimits(name, charge, leftMultiplier=1, rightMultiplier=1, ax=False)[source]¶

Fill in the area between the max and min limits of FWHM around the peak mean. (only use after calculating the mass spectrum fit).

Parameters:
  • name – Species name
  • charge – Charge to display
  • leftMultiplier – Value to multiply the peak fwhm below the mean
  • rightMultiplier – Value to multiply the peak fwhm above the mean
  • ax – Matplotlib Axes object or False to create one
Returns:

m/z limits when using multiplier as [lowerLimit,upperLimit]
plotSimulatedSpectrum(ax, xvals, speciesNames=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plots just the simulated mass spectrum as generated by self.leastSquaresOptimisation(), with a default color of red. All matplotlib.pyplot.plot() arguments are allowed in **kwargs.

plotTheoreticalMzs(ax, name, absolute=False, mass=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to draw the positions of calculated charge state peaks. Can be used with a Species() object stored in self.species by entering a ‘name’ or can be calculated directly from ‘mass’ If a value for absolute is given, it is used as the y axis position for charge state labels. All matplotlib.pyplot.plot() arguments are allowed in **kwargs.

writeCoordinatesToTxt(filename)[source]¶

Write the base mass spectrum data to file Each line is in the format of mz intensity (tab separated).

msClasses.Species module¶

Class to hold the information for molecular species which can used with MassSpectrum().

class msClasses.Species.Species(name)[source]¶

Holds the data for a single species. Separate objects should be created for before and after (auto) simulation

calculateMass(mzs)[source]¶

Calculate the mass of a molecular species using the given m/z values. Returns mass and error, where error is the average absolute difference between the given m/z values and the m/z from the calculated mass.

calculateMassAndCharges(mzs)[source]¶

Calculate the mass of a molecular species using the given m/z values. Primarily used as a subfunction of self.calculateMass().

getMz(z)[source]¶

Calculate the m/z value for a given charge state using the mass from self.mass

getPeakLimits(z, leftMultiplier=1.0, rightMultiplier=1.0)[source]¶

Returns lower and upper m/z limits for charge state peaks using self.peakFwhm as the original value, and using multipliers to alter the left and right limits independently.

getTotalArea(xvals)[source]¶

Calculate the area under the deconvoluted mass spectrum for just this species using the trapezium method of integration.

getTotalIntensity(xvals, yvals)[source]¶

Using the supplied data, sum the intensity of the highest point of the data at the m/z value for each charge state in self.charges using self.mass as the mass.

getp0(oneFwhm=0)[source]¶

Return the list of initial parameters for leastSquaresOptimisation() (in MassSpectrum()) from this Species() object.

plotTheoreticalMzs(ax, xvals, yvals, absolute=0, mass=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to draw the positions of calculated charge state peaks. If a value for absolute is given, it is used as the y axis position for charge state labels. All matplotlib.pyplot.plot() arguments are allowed in **kwargs.

setCharges(charges)[source]¶

For this molecular species, set the charges which are detected in the mass spectrometer.

setSpecies(gPeaks, peakFwhm=10)[source]¶

Setup this Species() object using gPeaks (d[id]=[mz,intensity]) Calculates the mass and estimates parameters for the other Species() parameters for later use as initial values for leastSquaresOptimisation() (MassSpectrum()).

setSpeciesGivenMass(mass, xvals, yvals, peakFwhm, zs)[source]¶

Similar to Species.setSpecies(). Except that instead of using gPeaks, the Species() object is setup automatically when given values for mass and the charges to be analysed.

setVals(mass, z_mu, z_amp, z_fwhh, p_fwhh=0)[source]¶

Set parameters for this object.

setValsFromp1(p1)[source]¶

After leastSquaresOptimisation() set the fitted parameters (p1) to this Species() object.

simulateSpecies(xvals, peakShape='hybrid')[source]¶

Simulates a mass spectrum using the object’s attributes Valid peak shapes are: ‘hybrid’, ‘gaussian’ & ‘lorentzian if one_fwhh is to be used be sure to set self.peakFwhm before calling this function.

msClasses.TwoDdata module¶

class msClasses.TwoDdata.TwoDdata[source]¶
addPeak(mz)[source]¶

This function allows you to add additional peaks not found using the findPeaks method

calculateAreaUnderCurve()[source]¶

Integrates data using trapezium method

calculateWeightedMeanStandardDeviation()[source]¶
findPeaks(limit=0)[source]¶

limit allows you to ignore slow peaks (remove noise) percentage of BPI e.g. 5 % cutoff should be 5

getAxesWithoutNans()[source]¶

The CCS calibration can cause some xvals to become NaNs, this function returns x and yvals truncated to remove the NaNs

normalisationArea()[source]¶
normalisationBpi()[source]¶

Normalise to base peak intensity (0-100)

plot(ax, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot 2D data (e.g. MS and ATDs) Can take matplotlib axes object, as well as any standard inputs for matplotlib.pyplot.plot().

plotgPeaks(ax, labels=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

if labels=0 then only peak id’s are displayed otherwise x-values are shown as well

readFile(filename, x_range=0, grain=1)[source]¶

Reads in x y coordinate pairs from text file ‘ ‘ separator as in copy spectrum list in MassLynx

x_range - allows you to select lower and upper bounds in the format of [lower,upper]

grain - allows the missing of data to speed up processing a grain of 2 means that every second value will be used

restoreRawYvals()[source]¶
setNormalisationType(type)[source]¶
smoothingSG(window_len=3, smoothes=2, poly_order=1)[source]¶

Should only really be used on equally spaced data Actual window length used is 2*window_len+1 to avoid breakage
